content.description: Start sitting with a low right hand sloper and a left hand good, slopey edge (both are foot holds for the regular start). Adds 4ish moves into the regular start. Shorter people will probably find it harder.
content.location: Backside of boulder, facing away from road, slightly down and left of the regular start.

content.description: Super fun climbing off a giant start hold. Figure your way up onto the right facing sloping rail either going left from the jug or right. Both felt about the same
content.location: Start on the giant jug at belly level on the far right corner of Angelina Jolie.

content.description: Classy slopers! Start sitting with both hands on the decent edge and (wo)manhandle some slopers and maybe a little crimp or two on the way to a dicey and technical topout on the slab. Use a heel hook or two, or don't; use an edge or two or just slap the sloper. Options abound on this problem and make it especially fun to try different small variations.
content.protection: A couple of pads for the very flat landing.
content.location: This is the first route visible as one approaches the boulder, facing the road. It's identifiable by a bulge festooned with numerous slopers.

content.description: Surprising interesting movement for such a small thing. Getting up the top was very friction/mantle fun
content.location: On the trail from Angelina Jolie towards the 420 boulders right off the trail. Its gotta large right facing low rail for the start

content.description:
Start on the waist height sidepull and go straight up on slopers. A little trickier than expected

.
content.location: This is on the left side of the boulder to the left side of the tree. You'll see the chalked up sidepull

climbs.name: Angelina Jolie
climbs.fa: Joel Campbell. Low start (V11): Tim Doyle

content.description: The perfect boulder problem: elegantly simple in appearance and hard as nails! This innocuous, slopey rail will entice, obsess and punish the unwary aspirant. Start with both hands on the far left of the rail (or, for the V11 start, on opposing edges below the rail) and climb up and right on perfect and desperate slopers. Requires that inimitable mix of tech-nine footwork and savage power so unique to granite. Cold weather doesn't hurt either.
content.protection: Pads for a flat but rocky landing.
content.location: This is the next route around to the right from Scrambled Eggs; the rail feature can't be missed.
